title: How (and When) to Harvest and Preserve Fennel: A Step-By-Step Guide

steps.title: Start collecting herb fennel leaves in late spring.
steps.content: Start collecting herb fennel leaves in late spring. Then, harvest any fennel stalks about 5-7 months after you first planted them. [1] X Research source Since fennel is an annual plant, it doesn’t last all year. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Cut off the fronds, not the stem.
steps.content: Cut off the fronds, not the stem. The fronds are thin, feathery strands attached to the stem, similar to a dill plant. Snip off these fronds in 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) pieces, leaving the rest of the plant intact. [3] X Research source Experts don’t specifically recommend refrigerating your fennel fronds. Instead, just cut off as much as you need. [4] X Research source These fronds add an elegant touch to your salads. Some chefs even like to add fennel fronds to their cooking water when they prepare rice and beans. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Fennel stalks are ready to harvest about 5-7 months after seeding.
steps.content: Fennel stalks are ready to harvest about 5-7 months after seeding. [6] X Research source Harvest these stalks with a pair of scissors or hand pruners, or a sharp knife. [7] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Fennel stalks are a tasty addition to fish dishes. You can also add your stalks to some homemade chicken stock. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Compared to other herbs, fennel stalks don’t stay fresh long.
steps.content: Compared to other herbs, fennel stalks don’t stay fresh long. For short-term storage, place the stalks in a loose plastic bag. Try to use them within 4 days, so the fennel tastes as fresh as possible. [9] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: A freezer-safe bag works well for long-term storage.
steps.content: A freezer-safe bag works well for long-term storage. Rinse off the herb fennel fronds and stalks with cool water, and then slide them into a freezer-safe bag. [10] X Research source Since there’s no official freezer recommendation for this plant, play it safe and freeze your fennel for 4-6 months. [11] X Research source Herb fennel is pretty similar to dill, and the freezer recommendation for dill is 4-6 months. Some people like to freeze their herbs in oil-filled ice cube trays. However, this freezing method doesn’t work well with soft, frond-like herbs. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Dried fennel stalks are good for up to 3 months.
steps.content: Dried fennel stalks are good for up to 3 months. Set your oven to 200 °F (93 °C) and place your fennel stalks on a cooking tray. Bake the stalks for 3 hours; then, switch off the oven and let the fennel dry out overnight. Once the stalks are dry, slip them into a sealed plastic bag. [13] X Research source If you have a little more time on your hands, tie your fennel stalks in bunches and leave them to air-dry in a dry, cool area for about 1-2 weeks.

steps.title: Wait until your fennel umbels turn brown.
steps.content: Wait until your fennel umbels turn brown. Then, cut the entire cluster off your fennel plant. The seeds form inside the flower heads, which is how you’ll harvest them. [14] X Research source If you wait too long, the seeds might shatter, and you won’t be able to collect them.

steps.title: Secure a paper bag along the bottom of the clusters.
steps.content: Secure a paper bag along the bottom of the clusters. Leave the fennel umbels hanging for a few days or weeks, or until you’ve collected a good amount of seeds. [15] X Research source Move your seeds to an airtight container and keep them in a cool, dark place, where they’ll stay fresh for up to 2 years. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Fennel bulbs are fully-grown after about 14 weeks.
steps.content: Fennel bulbs are fully-grown after about 14 weeks. [17] X Research source Harvest the bulb just before the plant starts flowering, when it’s tennis ball-sized. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Snip right below the bulb’s base, but leave the root in the soil.
steps.content: Snip right below the bulb’s base, but leave the root in the soil. Then, remove the entire plant from the soil. Sometimes, after you’ve harvested the bulb, small shoots will continue growing from the root, which you can collect later on. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Store your Florence fennel in a plastic bag.
steps.content: Store your Florence fennel in a plastic bag. Don’t wash or rinse it; instead, leave it in the refrigerator until you’re ready to use the bulb. Generally, bulb fennel stays fresh for at least a week. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Wash and blanche your fennel bulb before freezing it.
steps.content: Wash and blanche your fennel bulb before freezing it. To blanche the bulb, boil it for 3 minutes, and then soak it in cold water for a few minutes. Drain away any extra water, and slip it into a freezer-safe bag. [21] X Research source If your fennel looks discolored or feels soft after being in the freezer, throw it out.
